pages.text: Witches who left towns and villages gradually moved into forests and swamps, where they continued practicing magic hidden from curious and hostile outsiders. This period saw the emergence of the art of witchcraft, with an essential attribute being the solitary hut amidst forests or swamps. Many who have visited these witches describe their huts as larger inside than they appear from the outside.
Some forest witches opted for additional security measures. In the East, it is said that many huts could move because they had legs (strangely, chicken legs).

pages.title: Witch's Hut
pages.text: Even when towns ceased to be dangerous for witches, they did not return. Their magic thrived in swamps and forests, nourished by a constant connection to nature, remote and untouched by society. In these places, the power of witches is especially potent, and they are in no hurry to leave. If they must fight, they prefer to do so on their own turf.

pages.title: Witch's Hut
pages.text: One can encounter such a remarkable hut in the swamps. Getting inside won't be easy.
